description:
Hylaea fasciaria, commonly known as the Bordered Beauty, is a species of moth belonging to the family Geometridae. It is found across Europe and parts of Asia.

The Bordered Beauty has a wingspan of around 35-45 millimeters. The forewings are greyish-brown with distinctive darker brown bands, giving the wings a "bordered" appearance. The hindwings are paler in color. The larvae (caterpillars) are typically green with darker markings and feed on various coniferous trees, such as pine and spruce.

This species is nocturnal and attracted to artificial light sources. It plays an important role in forest ecosystems as a decomposer, with the larvae helping to recycle nutrients by feeding on needles and foliage. The Bordered Beauty is generally considered a common and widespread moth within its geographic range.
